questions.question: She ran with quick steps to the house when it …………………………. raining.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the past tense, we use a past tense in the subordinate clause as well.

questions.question: It was so quiet you ………………………. hear a pin drop.
questions.description: When the verb in the main clause is in the past tense, we use a past tense in the subordinate clause as well.

questions.question: Susie ……………………………. with her sister.
questions.description: We use the simple present to talk about permanent situations.

questions.question: She ……………………………… in the film industry for fifteen years by next year.
questions.description: The future perfect continuous is used to say that something will have been completed by a certain point of time in the future.

questions.question: The patient …………………………… before the doctor arrived.
questions.description: The past perfect is used to talk about the earlier of the two past actions.

questions.question: I …………………………………… this with him when he came here the other day.
questions.description: The past perfect is used to talk about the earlier of the two past actions. The simple past is also possible here.

questions.question: When I was young, I .................................... play football a lot.
questions.description: We use used to to talk about past habits.

questions.question: She ...................................... next month.
questions.description: The present continuous is used to talk about pre-planned future events.

questions.question: A good citizen ……………………………. all his financial obligations.
He …………………………. in this office for ten years now.
questions.description: The present perfect is used to talk about actions or situations that started in the past and has continued up to the present.

questions.question: You ……………………………… me you weren’t coming
questions.description: Could have + past participle can be used to criticize people for not doing things.

questions.question: If a sinner …………………………… penitence, he can be forgiven.
